channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Middle East Crisis: U.S. Plans New Sanctions on Iran After Attack on Israel
item.description: The Treasury secretary, Janet Yellen, said that new sanctions could be announced within days and would likely focus on limiting Iran’s oil exports.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Lays Out Protections for Assange if He Is Extradited
item.description: American officials sought to reassure the U.K. about Julian Assange’s treatment should the former WikiLeaks founder, who has been indicted by the U.S., be sent there.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Julian Assange, 52, was the head of WikiLeaks in 2010 when it published of tens of thousands of classified military and diplomatic documents leaked by Chelsea Manning, an Army intelligence analyst.

item.title: For Israel’s Allies, Iranian Missile Strike Scrambles Debate Over Gaza
item.description: Israel’s restless allies have voiced anger over the death toll in Gaza, but when their archnemesis launched a missile barrage, they set it aside. At least for the moment.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: A rocket booster that fell near Arad, Israel, after Iran launched drones and missiles over the weekend.

item.title: Ukraine’s Big Vulnerabilities: Ammunition, Soldiers and Air Defense
item.description: The shortages add up to a dire situation for Ukraine in the third year of the war, presenting commanders with near impossible choices on how to deploy limited resources.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of Ukraine’s 17th Tank Brigade near the front line in the Donetsk region in January.

item.title: Mayor Orders Police to Interrupt Conservative Conference in Brussels
item.description: Mayor Emir Kir gave no explanation of why he thought it necessary to try to stop the gathering from taking place, other than saying he wanted to “guarantee public safety.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Belgian police blocking the entrance of the Claridge, where the National Conservatism Conference was being held in Brussels on Tuesday.

item.title: The Paris Olympics’ One Sure Thing: Cyberattacks
item.description: “We will be attacked,” the official responsible for fending off cyberthreats said. To prepare, organizers have been hosting war games and paying “bug bounties” to hackers.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: The head of cyberattack preparations for the 2024 Paris Olympics said he expected to face billions of probing attacks against the Games’ computer networks.

item.title: Germany’s Leader, Olaf Scholz, Walks a Fine Line in China
item.description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz tried to promote German business interests while delivering warnings from Europe about trade and geopolitical tensions.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Melissa Eddy
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Michael Kappeler/dpa/Picture Alliance, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany with Xi Jinping, China’s leader, in Beijing on Tuesday.

item.title: Copenhagen’s Old Stock Exchange Building Partly Collapses in Fire
item.description: The 17th-century building, one of the city’s best-known structures, was once the financial center of Denmark.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Maya Tekeli
item.media:credit: Emil Helms/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Smoke billowing from the stock exchange building in Copenhagen on Tuesday.

item.title: On Himalayan Hillsides Grows Japan’s Cold, Hard Cash
item.description: A shrub in impoverished Nepal now supplies the raw material for the bank notes used in Asia’s most sophisticated financial system.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma, Alex Travelli and Uma Bista
item.media:description: Workers cleaning argeli bark in the Ilam district of eastern Nepal. Thousands of miles away, in Japan, the bark will be used to make yen notes.

item.title: Expert Panel Calls on Germany to Legalize Abortion in First 12 Weeks
item.description: For decades, Germany allowed early abortions even while keeping them illegal. A government-appointed commission says the system is “untenable.”
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: From left, Lisa Paus, the German minister for family affairs, senior citizens and women and youth; Karl Lauterbach, the health minister; and Marco Buschmann, the justice minister, at a news conference in Berlin on Monday.

item.title: Far Right’s Ties to Russia Sow Rising Alarm in Germany
item.description: As cases proliferate, opponents fear the Alternative for Germany party is becoming a tool of Russian influence operations to undermine support for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: A protest against the Alternative for Germany party, or AfD, in January in Rostock, Germany. It was one of many around the country.

item.title: One Year of Civil War in Sudan: What We Know About the Conflict
item.description: The fighting between two generals leading competing military factions has now been going on for a year, leading to massacres, hunger and a massive wave of people fleeing their homes.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: The aftermath of an aerial bombardment, during clashes between the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces and the Sudanese army in Khartoum North, Sudan, in May 2023.

item.title: Was It Hatred of Women? Australia Asks After Stabbing Rampage.
item.description: All but three of the 18 people killed or injured Saturday were women. While the attacker’s motive may never be known, many said the episode spoke to a larger problem.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: A memorial at Bondi Junction in Sydney, Australia, on Monday, after six people were killed last weekend.

item.title: A Show of Might in the Skies Over Israel
item.description: Iran’s retaliation for Israel’s killing of senior military leaders was a highly choreographed spectacle. But fears of a wider war still loom.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Farnaz Fassihi, Aaron Boxerman, Patrick Kingsley and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: More than 300 drones and missiles hurtled toward Israel through Iraqi and Jordanian airspace on Saturday night.

item.title: Did Three African Runners Let a Chinese Runner Win a Race in Beijing?
item.description: Organizers are investigating the results of the Beijing Half Marathon, after three runners from Kenya and Ethiopia appeared to wave a Chinese competitor past them before the finish.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Chinese runner He Jie, Ethiopian Dejene Hailu Bikila and Kenyans Robert Keter and Willy Mnangat taking part in a half-marathon in Beijing on Sunday.

item.title: UN Panel Says Israel Is Obstructing Its Investigation of the Oct. 7 Attack
item.description: The commission, which is looking at possible human rights violations by Hamas and Israel, said it had still amassed large amounts of evidence. Israel has accused the commission of bias.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Navi Pillay, right, who leads a U.N. commission created to look into possible human rights violations by Israel, with the Egyptian ambassador to the U.N., Ahmed Ihab Abdelahad Gamaleldin, in Geneva on Tuesday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A chance for U.S. aid to Ukraine and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.category: New York State Criminal Case Against Trump (71543-23)
item.media:description: The aid package that Mike Johnson is advancing mirrors the $95 billion aid bill the Senate passed two months ago.

item.title: Microsoft Makes High-Stakes Play in Tech Cold War With Emirati A.I. Deal
item.description: Microsoft said it would invest $1.5 billion in G42, an Emirati company with ties to China, as Washington and Beijing maneuver to secure tech influence in the Persian Gulf.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times

item.title: Israel Weighs Response to Iran’s Attack as Allies Push for Restraint
item.description: The Israeli war cabinet met again on Monday to discuss the strike, with some hawkish members of the prime minister’s government calling for a swift and forceful retaliation.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd, Isabel Kershner and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathering in Tehran on Monday to show their support for Iran’s attack on Israel.

item.title: Israeli Settlers Kill Two Palestinian Men in the West Bank, Officials Say
item.description: The Israeli military said the men were killed during a “violent exchange” that followed a report of a Palestinian attacking an Israeli shepherd.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Burned vehicles in the Palestinian village of Al Mughayir, in the West Bank, on Saturday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Donald Trump’s Trial Begins
item.description: Also, Israel weighs a response to Iran and Sudan marks a year of war.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump in Manhattan court on Monday.

item.title: Lebanese Official Blames Israel’s Spy Agency for Killing Near Beirut
item.description: The U.S. had accused the dead man of being a financial middleman between Hamas and Iran. The interior minister said there were suggestions that the killing “was carried out by intelligence services.”
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: Lebanon’s interior minister, Bassam Mawlawi, said initial findings suggested that the killing of a money changer “was carried out by intelligence services.”

item.title: Pro-Palestinian Protests Block Golden Gate Bridge and Other U.S. Hubs
item.description: The coordinated protests across the United States and around the globe were planned in part to coincide with Tax Day in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Colbi Edmonds
item.media:credit: Brontë Wittpenn/San Francisco Chronicle, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Pro-Palestinian protesters shutting down traffic on I-880 in Oakland, Calif., on Monday.

item.title: Britain’s Leaders Condemn Iran’s Attacks but Urge Israel to Show Restraint
item.description: Rishi Sunak said the government in Tehran was “intent on sowing chaos” in the region, but he also called for restraint from “all sides.”
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak recording a statement on Iran’s attack on Israel, in London on Sunday.

item.title: Ukraine Sees ‘Hypocrisy’ After Western Allies Helped Intercept Iran’s Attack on Israel
item.description: The U.S., British and French militaries helped intercept Iranian missiles and drones, but Ukrainians say they haven’t provided the same help against Russian air attacks.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A boy rides a donkey near one of the batteries of Israel’s Iron Dome missile defense system in the southern Negev desert on Sunday.

item.title: Iran’s Strike on Israel Creates Military Uncertainty, Diplomatic Opportunity
item.description: Analysts feared Iran’s strikes might set off a wider war. But with Israel still weighing its response, the attack’s military and diplomatic consequences have yet to be determined.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: A billboard showing Iranian missiles, on a road in Tehran on Monday.

item.title: Al Gore Thinks Trump Will Lose and Climate Activists Will Triumph
item.description: Mr. Gore spoke at a climate leadership conference hosted by his nonprofit organization.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Calla Kessler for The New York Times

item.title: Netanyahu Weighs Response to Iran, Wary of Alienating Biden
item.description: Its options range from striking Iran openly and forcefully to doing nothing at all. One factor to weigh is that the huge aerial attack did little damage.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: An Israeli army vehicle headed toward Gaza on Monday.

item.title: With Nuclear Deal Dead, Containing Iran Grows More Fraught
item.description: The U.S., Europe, Russia and China worked together on a 2015 deal to limit Iran’s nuclear program. The arrangement’s unraveling and the spike in superpower tensions make this a dangerous moment.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: With the latest escalation of tensions between Iran and Israel, President Biden’s political opponents are now blaming the administration for having not taken a tougher line in recent years against Iran.

item.title: In Australia, a Validation of Sorts for Brittany Higgins
item.description: More than three years after Brittany Higgins went public with her claim of rape, her case reached a conclusion of sorts.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Bruce Lehrmann leaving court in Sydney, Australia, on Monday.

item.title: Scientists Predict Most Extensive Coral Bleaching Event on Record
item.description: Rising sea temperatures around the planet have caused a bleaching event that is expected to be the most extensive on record.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:description: Bleached coral off the Keppel Islands, Australia, at the southern end of the Great Barrier Reef, last month.

item.title: Tesla Will Lay Off More Than 10% of Global Workforce
item.description: Along with the departure of two senior executives, the cuts added to signs of turmoil at the electric car company.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tesla reported a decline in sales this month that caught investors off guard.

item.title: Families of Manchester Bombing Victims File Lawsuit Against MI5
item.description: The suit comes after an independent public inquiry said the 2017 bombing at an Ariana Grande concert was a “significant missed opportunity” for the U.K. spy agency.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz and Ali Watkins
item.media:description: A memorial in 2017 for victims of the bombing, which killed 22 people.

item.title: Bishop Stabbed in Sydney Church, 2 Days After Deadly Mall Attack
item.description: A 15-year-old boy has been arrested in the attack, in which several people were injured. An official said the episode appeared to have been motivated by religious extremism.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Claire Moses
item.media:description: In this still image from a livestreamed video posted on social media, an attacker approaches Bishop Mar Mari Emmanuel during a service at an Assyrian Orthodox church on Monday.

item.title: Biden and Other Israeli Allies Urge Against Further Escalation After Iran Attack
item.description: Some far-right members of the Israeli government called for a strong response to an Iranian attack, but the U.S., the E.U. and others cautioned against further escalation.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: An Israeli fighter jet taking off in central Israel on Sunday.

item.title: Oil Prices Lower After Iran’s Attack on Israel
item.description: Investors are taking a wait-and-see approach after the much-anticipated aerial assault had little effect on oil supplies.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:description: An oil tanker off the coast of Bandar Abbas, Iran, last year. Oil prices had increased substantially in the days before Iran’s attack on Israel.

item.title: Here are the latest developments.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Aaron Boxerman

item.title: With Iran’s Strikes, Arab Countries Fear an Expanding Conflict
item.description: The Iranian attack on Israeli territory made the Middle East’s new reality undeniable: Clashes are getting harder and harder to contain.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin and Vivian Nereim
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The interior of a house near Arad, Israel, that was struck in the Iranian missile attack.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: After Iran’s attack, Israel weighs its options.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Missile debris that was collected by the police outside Arad, Israel, on Sunday.

item.title: Israel Questions What’s Next for the Gaza War
item.description: Military analysts are divided on whether a more direct confrontation with Iran might alter the war or affect a decision to invade the southern city of Rafah.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Residents removing possessions and inspecting their homes after Israeli airstrikes in Khan Younis, Gaza, on Saturday.

item.title: Gazans Trying to Return Home Say Israeli Troops Fired on Them
item.description: An emergency worker and two people who tried to make the journey said Israeli troops shot into the crowd, forcing people to turn back in panic.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Ameera Harouda
item.media:description: Displaced Palestinians passing through the central Gaza Strip as they try to return to northern Gaza on Sunday.

item.title: A 7-Year-Old Girl Is the Lone Serious Casualty of Iran’s Barrage
item.description: The girl, who lives in a Negev desert community that is home to Arab Bedouins, was clinging to life in a hospital after the attack.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Natan Odenheimer
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Amina al-Hasoni’s house in the village of al-Fur’ah, Israel, the Iranian attack wounded her and ripped holes in the roof and floor.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Israel Weighs a Response to Iran
item.description: Also, the Australian authorities are searching for a motive in the deadly stabbing attack.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Holes in the roof and floor at the home of 7-year-old girl who was injured by missiles sharpnel outside Arad, Israel, on Sunday.

item.title: Johnson Says the House Will Vote on an Israel Bill in the Coming Days
item.description: Speaker Mike Johnson left unclear whether the vote on the security package, coming after Iranian attacks on Israel, would also include aid for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: “We’re going to try again this week,” Speaker Mike Johnson said on Sunday about voting on a bill to aid Israel.

item.title: Iran Attack Tests Netanyahu’s Political Staying Power
item.description: In a deeply polarized country that has again come under attack, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s fate may depend on what happens next.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu presenting Iranian nuclear program documents in Tel Aviv in 2018.

item.title: Strikes Upend Israel’s Belief About Iran’s Willingness to Fight It Directly
item.description: Israel had grown used to targeting Iranian officials without head-on retaliation from Iran, an assumption overturned by Iran’s attacks on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iran’s attacks were in response to a strike by Israel in Syria that killed seven Iranian officials, including three top military commanders. Attendees at a rally in Tehran this month donned masks representing the officials who were killed.

item.title: Jordan Says It Shot Down Iranian Drones As Act of Self-Defense
item.description: The Arab kingdom said it took military action to defend its territory against Iranian drone and missile strikes. Critics assailed the country as having helped defend Israel.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: An image taken from video shows people standing around the debris of a missile that the Jordanian forces intercepted over Amman during Iran’s bombardment of Israel early Sunday.

item.title: What We know About Iran Firing at Least 300 Drones and Missiles at Israel
item.description: Israel is deciding how to respond to an attack by Tehran in which it fired hundreds of drones and missiles. Its allies are urging restraint.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Explosions over Israel on Sunday. Iran’s attack was a retaliation for airstrikes on an Iranian Embassy building in Syria this month.

item.title: Iran’s Strikes on Israel Open a Dangerous New Chapter for Old Rivals
item.description: Experts say Tehran does not want a broader war. But it is far from clear whether Iran or Israel will choose to escalate a conflict that has become more direct and out of the shadows.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Missile parts collected by the police outside Arad, Israel, on Sunday. Iran launched hundreds of drones and missiles toward Israel overnight.

item.title: Biden Seeks to Head Off Escalation After Israel’s Successful Defense
item.description: The president told Israel that the interception of nearly all of the Iranian drones and missiles used to attack it constituted a major victory, and so further retaliation might not be necessary, U.S. officials said.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden on Saturday outside the White House. He is trying to convince Israel that its defense against the Iranian attack is a victory.

item.title: Israel Used Iron Dome and Arrow 3 Systems to Block Attack
item.description: Israel’s Iron Dome defense system intercepts rockets that fly in high arcs, while its Arrow 3 system can stop ballistic missiles outside the atmosphere.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Israel’s Iron Dome defense system intercepting rockets launched last year from the Gaza Strip over Sderot, Israel.

item.title: A History of the Shadow War Between Iran and Israel
item.description: The volley of drones and missiles was the first time that Tehran directly attacked Israel from its own territory, one expert said.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: Emergency workers searched the rubble of a building that was part of the Iranian Embassy complex in Damascus, Syria, a day after the April 1 airstrike.

item.title: After Bondi Stabbing Rampage, Australia Asks How and Why
item.description: The police have yet to determine a motive for Saturday’s attack, which left six people dead, but said the assailant had mental-health problems.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A memorial in Bondi Junction, a suburb of Sydney, Australia, on Sunday, a day after six people were killed in a stabbing rampage.

item.title: Israel Faced a Sophisticated Attack From Iran
item.description: The weapons Iran employed this weekend travel farther and are more precise than those Hamas and other allies have used against Israel in the past six months.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Drones or missiles being fired at Israel from Iran early Sunday.

item.title: She Was Kidnapped a Decade Ago With 275 Girls. Finally, She Escaped.
item.description: Their capture set off a global campaign to “Bring Back Our Girls.” But many are still missing, and kidnappings in Nigeria have proliferated.
item.dc:creator: Ismail Alfa and Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Taiwo Aina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Saratu Dauda shares what happened after the terrorist group Boko Haram abducted her and her classmates.

item.title: U.S. Intercepts Dozens of Iranian Drones and Missiles Aimed at Israel
item.description: Britain’s defense secretary said British jets were prepared to intercept Iranian attacks. France and Germany expressed support.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: A U.S. Marine outside the Oval Office, indicating President Biden was there on Saturday evening after Iran began attacking Israel.

item.title: Tensions Flare in West Bank After Israeli Teenager Is Found Dead
item.description: The killing, which Israel called a “terrorist attack,” prompted rioting by Israeli settlers that killed one Palestinian and raised fears of a broader escalation.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Christopher F. Schuetze and Julia Jacobs
item.media:description: Israeli settlers torched cars and buildings in Al Mughayir in the West Bank on Saturday, Palestinian officials said.

item.title: State Dept. Is Sending Its Top Diplomat for East Asia to China
item.description: The announcement comes days after President Biden met jointly with the leaders of Japan and the Philippines to discuss Chinese aggression in the Indo-Pacific region.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi
item.media:description: Daniel J. Kritenbrink, the assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, will travel to China on Sunday.

item.title: 6 Stabbed at Bondi Junction Mall in Sydney: What We Know
item.description: The attack happened in a busy center for tourists and beachgoers in the eastern suburbs, an affluent area of Sydney.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Dean Lewins/Australian Associated Press, via Reuters
item.media:description: People paying their respects on Sunday at a memorial for the victims of Saturday’s mass stabbing in Bondi Junction in Sydney, Australia.

item.title: Stabbing Attack in Sydney Kills At Least 6
item.description: Shoppers hid in backrooms or ran screaming from the scene, while others stayed with injured victims. The police said they believed the attack was not a “terrorism incident.”
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai, Yan Zhuang and John Yoon
item.media:description: Emergency vehicles lined the street outside the Westfield Bondi Junction shopping mall in Australia on Saturday, after a stabbing attack killed six and injured at least two others.

item.title: Protesters in Niger Call for U.S. Military Exit
item.description: Trainers and equipment from Russia landed in the West African nation this week, putting the continued presence of 1,000 U.S. military personnel there in doubt.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Protesters on Saturday in Niger’s capital, Niamey. Some carried Russian flags alongside Niger’s green, white and orange version.
